title: Watling Street
summary: Watling Street is a historic route in England that crosses the River Thames at London and which was used in Classical Antiquity, Late Antiquity, and throughout the Middle Ages. It was used by the ancient Britons and paved as one of the main Roman roads in Britannia â€“ Roman-governed Great Britain during the Roman Empire. The route linked Dover and London in the southeast via St Albans to Wroxeter to the northwest. Watling Street was the traditional site of the Romans' Defeat of Boudica, the line of the road was later the southwestern border of the Danelaw with Wessex and Mercia, and Watling Street was numbered as one of the major highways of medieval England.
